column4: Hello everyone.. I have some text files edited on a windows computer and I need to make them work nicely on my ubuntu machine.. some of the international characters isn't the same but linefeeds and newlines are still working.. there has to be some kind of converter I can use.. any hints?
many of them, and do you know the encoding they're currently using?
gedit actually has a "Character Coding" option in its load and save dialogs. Or you can use something like iconv if you prefer the command line.
what windows xp create by default =).. I can see if enca has anything wise to say about it
enca didn't recognize it.. file says it's a "Non-ISO extended-ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators"
I'll give gedit a try, thanks
what windows (notepad?) saved it as may depend on what locale windows thinks you're in
it's actually matlab .. but I guess that editor is as smart as notepad
and it's pretty much impossible for tools (like file) to reliably detect the encoding if it's one of the one-byte-per-codepoint ones
yup.. I know
thanks for your help
hope you can figure out what encoding it is actually in...
that wouldn't give you an orbit process. It's a different protocol.
ok.. I've never messed with it.. so I'm really just guessing..
don't start now, it's slowly on its way out (mainly replaced by dbus)
how are you checking, and is it running gnome?
bleh, I'm wrong, there's no actual orbit process
I checked my running processes, configuration files.. anything starting with 'orb'.. doesn't find anything
you're correct, the sockets are just used by a couple of gnome processes. Check with fuser or lsof if you really want to know :)
ahh.. lots and lots of open files.. but it seems that it's only the folder that is called orbit.. not the process in itself..
exactly (it's a library, used by things like gconf and the panel)
